abstract.p: We study institutional herding in Japan. Japanese firms are primarily owned by financial institutions and other corporations, they may belong to a business group (thekeiretsu), and they have experienced several distinct economic regimes in its recent past. Overall, we find herding in Japan occurs on a lower level than in the United States but with a large impact on price movements. The price impact is even greater forkeiretsu-affiliated firms. We also find the effects and behavior of institutional herding depends on the economic condition and the regulatory environment.

body.p: Herding occurs when a group of investors buy or sell the same security based on the same, or correlated, information signals, over some period of time. The recent literature empirically confirms that institutions herd, primarily as positive feedback (or momentum) traders and their herding moves prices. To date, these studies have investigated U.S. data (see Grinblatt, Titman, and Wermers1995; Nofsinger and Sias1999; and Wermers1999). While these studies provide important insights on U.S. markets and institutional shareholders, the applicability of these findings to other markets is questionable. For example, institutional investors in some countries build a long‐term relationship with the firms in which they own stock (e.g., see LaPorta, Lopez‐DeSilanes, and Shleifer1999), unlike in the United States. Additionally, institutional shareholdings are often an integral component of a business group, which is often made up of numerous businesses and financial institutions. These kinds of organizational structures are prevalent in many countries around the world, especially in emerging countries (LaPorta et al.1999) but not in the United States. Does herding exist in these environments? If so, then is it based on feedback trading, or some other signal? And does it move prices? To address these and other important questions and improve our overall understanding of institutional herding, we study Japan.

There are many important reasons for studying institutional herding in Japan. First, as pointed out by Roe (1990), Japanese institutions face fewer legal and political restrictions (relative to the United States) with regard to owning equity. This environment has allowed Japanese institutional investors to build long‐term relationships with the firms that they own. The nature of these relationships facilitates information flow between shareholders and their firms. As such, Japanese institutional investors are known as influential, active, and “aligned” shareholders for the firms in which they own shares, which is unlike the United States, where many institutions seem to have a shorter‐term focus. Therefore, Japanese institutions may have different herding characteristics than U.S. institutions.

Second, Japan has an organizational form known askeiretsu, business groups of diverse firms that have close relationships with one another. These relationships are bonded through cross‐shareholding. Furthermore, financial institutions belonging to these groups are not only large stockholders of member firms but also important creditors to member firms. Such close long‐term relationships allow for these institutions to have better private information about the firm than “outside” investors. By contrastingkeiretsufirms to non‐keiretsufirms, we are able to provide insights on business group behavior.

Third, by studying Japan, we also have the opportunity to observe institutional herding and feedback trading under four distinct economic regimes. Prior to the early 1980s, the Japanese financial markets were heavily regulated. After a round of deregulation during the early 1980s, the Japanese market enjoyed tremendous growth (this era is commonly referred to as Japan's “bubble” period), but at the beginning of the 1990s, the bubble burst and the economy and stock market entered an extended bear market. For example, the Tokyo Stock Price Index (TOPIX) peaked at over 2800 in 1990, but during the 1990s it gradually lost more than half of its value. In partial response to the declining market, Japan further deregulated its financial markets under a series of reforms perhaps best‐known as the “Big Bang.” We examine whether different economic environments lead to different institutional trading behaviors and outcomes, which represents an investigation that has yet to be done using U.S. data.

We investigate the impact, the nature, and the outcome of Japanese institutional herding in the following straightforward manner. Specifically, we examine the relationship between herding and (1) the herded stocks' concurrent year's returns, (2) the herded stocks' prior year's returns, and (3) the herded stocks' subsequent year's returns and herding level. The null hypotheses, naturally, are that herding has no relationship with any of these returns. We conduct further investigations by contrastingkeiretsufirms and independent firms and examining subperiods to see if different economic regimes lead to different kinds of herding and feedback trading. Again, the null hypotheses are that there is no difference in the nature of herding betweenkeiretsufirms and independent firms and no difference in herding among subperiods. Overall, our paper's results reject these null hypotheses.

The next section outlines some of the key aspects to the nature of Japanese institutional investors that are relevant to our study. In section II, we present our general findings on herding in Japan. In section III, we investigate the relationship between herding and business groups. Section IV examines subperiods characterized by different economic regimes. Finally, the last section offers a summary and a conclusion.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: The Nature of Japanese Institutional Investors
sec.p: Prowse (1990,1992) relates how the corporate governance and ownership structure is different in Japan compared to the United States. For the United States, Roe (1990) states that the political and legal environment restricts U.S. institutional investors from exerting effective control. For example, U.S. life insurance companies are subject to strict regulation of their equity investments (Cummins1977), the Glass‐Steagall Act prohibits U.S. commercial banks from owning stock on their own accounts, and U.S. pension funds are discouraged from voting the shares they own (Prowse1990). In stark contrast and consistent with observations made by Prowse (1990,1992), Roe contends that institutions in Japan are given more latitude to own shares and exert control over firms. As a consequence, the long‐term shareholders in Japan tend to be banks and insurance companies. In addition to financial firms, corporate cross‐shareholders are also important long‐term shareholders (Flath1993; Berglöf and Perotti1994; and Aoki, Patrick, and Sheard1994). Prowse (1992) provides some Japanese ownership evidence supporting these claims. He finds that banks and insurance companies own over one‐third of Japanese corporations' outstanding equity and Japanese nonfinancial firms own 24% of the outstanding equity. For the United States, the comparable figures are less than 5% and 11%, respectively.

The presence and impact of the long‐term “stable” shareholdings onto corporate financing and investment structure is significant. For example, Kang and Stulz (1996) contend that Japanese managers focus on long‐term objectives rather than short‐run profits because they are working in the interest of their long‐term shareholders. Likewise, due to the long‐term presence that shareholders commit to the firm, they will engage in active monitoring (Berglöf and Perotti1994; Kang and Shivdasani1995; and Prowse1992). Among all institutional shareholders, financial institutions are often viewed as being particularly important, because they usually own significant equity stakes and are the most important creditors to the firm. As argued by Hoshi, Kashyap, and Scharfstein (1991), having active financial firms as shareholders and lenders overcomes the constraints (e.g., asymmetric information and incentive problems) that usually exist in capital markets. In turn, as a result of their dual equity and credit stakes, financial institutions are active with regard to monitoring and influencing corporate financing and investment policies (Hoshi, Kashyap, and Scharfstein 1990, 1991; Kang, Shivdasani, and Yamada2000; Kester1986; and Prowse1990). Corporate cross‐shareholders are also active in monitoring. They often understand each other's business operations better than their financial institutional shareholders, so they can cross‐monitor one another effectively (Aoki, Patrick, and Sheard1994and Berglöf and Perotti1994). As a result, institutional shareholders in Japan enjoy reduced asymmetric information problems and agency costs as compared to U.S. institutional investors (Hoshi, Kashyap, Scharfstein1990,1991; Prowse1990; and Berglöf and Perotti1994).

Many of these Japanese governance and shareholding characteristics are posited to be intensified if a firm belongs to akeiretsu, which is an industrial organization characterized by many firms grouped into an affiliation through the cross‐ownership of stock, business ties, and bank lending. This close relationship is the source of a “teamwork” approach between the members of akeiretsu. For example,keiretsucorporate cross‐shareholders actively monitor each other,keiretsumember banks often work closely with member firms, and these banks provide important lending to their member firms (Berglöf and Perotti1994; Hoshi, Kashyap, and Scharfstein1990; Kester1986; Morck and Nakamura1999; and Sheard1989). In addition,keiretsumembers provide financial assistance to troubled firms as a way of overcoming the discipline and financial constraints of the external capital markets (Hoshi, Kashyap, and Scharstein1991). This financing relationship amongkeiretsumembers likely adds to the quality of the cross‐owners' inside information. As such, research has found that, while Japanese firms as a group experience less information asymmetry and agency problems, these benefits are much greater forkeiretsufirms (e.g., Berglöf and Perotti1994; Hoshi, Kashyap, and Scharfstein1991). Note that this contention implies thatkeiretsufirm shareholders are likely to be “better” at herding.

Overall, Japanese institutional investors suffer less from an asymmetric information problem than U.S. institutions, and Japanese institutional investors tend to be long‐term shareholders. As a result, many Japanese institutions have close relationships with firms in which they own shares. Thus, Japanese institutional shareholders may be characterized as “aligned” and well‐informed shareholders. This sense of alignment and the reduced information asymmetry are posited to be much stronger if a firm belongs to akeiretsu. As a result, herding behaviors and their impacts may be different from what we see in the United States. For example, the magnitude of herding may be less, there may be less need to rely on perceived proxies of firm value in investment decision making, and the purpose for herding may not be related to capturing short‐run profits.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Herding
sec.p: There are several theoretical foundations for why institutional herding may exist. Investigative herding results when investors follow the same or similar signals of the firm's value (Froot, Scharfstein, and Stein1992and Hirshleifer, Subrahmanyam, and Titman1994). Because we argue that Japanese institutional investors experience reduced information asymmetry, this is the most likely cause of their herding. That is, the future prospects of the firm are known to “aligned” institutions, and they make trading decisions at the same time.

Alternatively, U.S. institutional investors experience higher information asymmetry. Having less private information, U.S. institutions may herd on firm characteristics they percieve are correlated with firm value, such as return momentum (DeLong, Shleifer, Summers, and Waldmann1990; Del Guercio1996; and Gompers and Metrick2001). Or, institutions may infer information from each other's trades (Banerjee1992and Bihkchandani, Hirshleifer, and Welch1992). The resulting “informational cascade” causes a string of institutional herding over time. U.S. institutional herding has been found to be reflective of herding models based on the characterization that they suffer high information asymmetry and must infer firm value from various signals, like return momentum or the trades of other institutions (see Grinblatt, Titman, and Wermers1995; Nofsinger and Sias1999; and Sias2004).

To examine herding in Japan, we study the relationship between changes in institutional ownership and abnormal returns. We defineinstitutional ownershipas the fraction of outstanding shares owned by Japanese institutional investors.1The level of herding is indicated by the amount of average ownership change.

Is Japanese institutional herding, if it exists, associated with investigative herding, informational cascades, or momentum trading? By examining the relationship between the change in ownership and abnormal returns over various periods, we can determine the extent and the type of Japanese institutional herding that exists. For example, the relation between the herding‐year change in ownership and the change in the prior year tests whether the institutions may be following each other's trades (informational cascade). The relation between herding and past returns tests the extent to which investors momentum (positive feedback) trade. Last, we examine the post herding year abnormal returns. We examine abnormal returns 1 year after the herding period to identify whether prices experience subsequent momentum or reversals. Nofsinger and Sias (1999) argue that price momentum after herding is consistent with the herding moving prices toward equilibrium and is thus stabilizing. The concern is that momentum traders drive the prices of high‐performing stocks even higher, and ultimately cause a price bubble. Therefore, dramatic price reversals after herding would be indicative of destabilizing behavior.

fn.p: The Anti‐Monopoloy Act of 1977 (which became effective in 1987) forced banks to reduce their ownership stakes, in any one firm, from 10% to 5%. Therefore, the act could ambiguously affect our results, especially during the 1980s. However, we do not believe that our herding measure is significantly affected by the act, as we use an aggregate ownership measure and it is well known that other affiliated institutional buyers took up the slack. For details in this regard, see Kim and Limpaphayom (1998, page 42). Furthermore, a subsequent subperiod analysis, discussed later in the paper, reveals that our key findings are quite robust across all sample periods.

sec.title: Data and Methods
sec.p: Our monthly stock returns, annual institutional ownership, and firm capitalization data for Japanese firms come from the Pacific‐Basin Capital Markets (PACAP) Research Center, which obtains stock price data from the Daiwa Institute of Research Ltd. and ownership data from Toyo Kezai Inc. For each firm, annual aggregate ownership data is reported at the end of each fiscal year (usually March 31) for the years 1975‐2001, and it is available for the following owner‐types: government, financial institutions, securities companies, other business corporations, foreigners, and individuals.2We define institutions as (Japanese) domestic financial institutions, securities companies, and business companies. In 1975 (2001), for example, these institutional investors owned approximately 58% (57%) of the outstanding shares while individual investors owned 40% (37%).3Note that our ownership data are observed on only one day during the year. As such, we will discuss the implications of using annual ownership observations later in the paper. The sample of firms with ownership data, monthly returns, and market‐capitalization varies from 1,232 (in 1975) to 1,928 (in 2001). The total sample comprises 39,408 firm‐years of data.

Daniel, Titman and Wei (2001) find that firm size and book‐to‐market variables are important determinants of returns in Japan. However, their tests reject the Fama‐French three‐factor model for the Japanese stock market. Therefore, the abnormal returns reported in this study are capitalization and book‐to‐market adjusted returns. To compute abnormal returns, we do the following. We sort each firm (each year) into 10 portfolios by their beginning of year market capitalization. We follow this same procedure to form 10 portfolios by their book‐to‐market equity ratio. We then use these capitalization and book‐to‐market deciles to create 100 size and book‐to‐market portfolios. The abnormal return for each month is the firm's return less the return from the one portfolio (out of 100) to which the firm belongs. This procedure controls for the size bias and book‐to‐market bias in returns.

To test for herding and feedback trading we follow the methods of Nofsinger and Sias (1999). Their procedure is designed to create 10 portfolios, each year, that have similar institutional ownership at the beginning of each year and large differences in the change in institutional ownership over the year. We summarize their procedure as follows. All firms are sorted into 10 portfolios based on the fraction of institutional ownership at the beginning of each fiscal year (which predominately begins in April). Within each of these portfolios, firms are sorted into 10 more portfolios based on the change in institutional ownership over the fiscal year; that is, change is measured as the current year's percent of institutional ownership minus the previous year's percent of institutional ownership, so if institutions owned 10% of a firm at the beginning of the year and 15% of the firm at the end of the year, then we record the change for the year as 5% (or 0.05). This leaves 10 institutional‐change portfolios within each of the 10 institutional‐level portfolios. Now we begin to reaggregate the firms. First, we combine each of the 10 lowest‐decile institutional‐change portfolios from the institutional‐level portfolios. Then we combine each of the second‐lowest‐decile change portfolios. We continue until we are left with 10 portfolios each year that have similar institutional ownership at the beginning of the year but experience different changes in institutional ownership over the year. Recall that our sorting procedure is designed so that all 10 portfolios have similar institutional ownership at the beginning of the year. To confirm that we did this successfully, we note that every portfolio has an average 64% of shares held by institutional owners at the beginning of each year. AnF‐statistic of 0.12 indicates that the initial level of institutional ownership is not different among portfolios. More important, on average, the change in institutional ownership for the largest decrease decile is −6.15% per year. The change in institutional ownership monotonically increases across the 10 portfolios to a 7.4% increase in the largest increase portfolio. AnF‐statistic, reporting the test that the change in institutional ownership across the 10 portfolios is equal, rejects equality at the 1% level.

Does this mean that Japanese institutional investors herd? For example, it is possible that we are identifying the investing behavior of a single institutional investor or one type of institutional investor. We think both these possibilities are unlikely. First, the total number of shares that institutions purchase (decile 10) and give up (decile 1) each firm‐year is approximately 5‐7 million shares valued at $40‐50 million U.S. We doubt that single institutions are making these large trades. Prowse (1992) finds that even the largest Japanese institutional shareholders are wealth constrained. Second, while our ownership data cannot identify how many institutions are buying or selling shares, we can identify if a specific type of institution is driving the ownership change results; and we find that this is not the case. We find that financial institutions and business corporations each account for half of the decile 1 and 10 ownership changes. Therefore, we feel comfortable with the assumption of Nofsinger and Sias (1999) that firms with the largest institutional ownership changes occur as a result of herding.

Nofsinger and Sias (1999) find that U.S. institutions have a much larger change in ownership throughout the year. Using this procedure and a similar time period (1977‐95), their findings are reported in panel B of ourtable 1. First, note that their initial institutional ownership level is almost half that for Japan. Again, this confirms differences in the environment for corporate ownership between Japan and the United States. Just as important, note that they find that the largest decrease (increase) institutional ownership portfolio experiences a change of −15.95% (18.30%) for New York Stock Exchanges listed firms. At the extremes, Japanese institutional ownership changed in a magnitude representing approximately one‐third that experienced by U.S. institutional ownership changes. While institutional herding appears to exist in Japan, we see that it occurs at a lower level than in the United States.4

fn.p: In Japan, a firm must report its shareholder profile in its annual report, which must be filed within 3 months after the fiscal‐year end. The most timely and easy way for market participants to obtain corporate financial and ownership data is to subscribe to a database from an independent private firm. Database vendors claim that they can compile and store data into their online databases for client subscribers as soon as the data are released. Toyo Keizai and Nikkei are the two major Japanese firms that provide this service. The database used in our study comes from the Pacific‐Basin Capital Markets Research Center, which is an academic database containing historical stock price, financial statement, and other corporate data. The PACAP database's ownership data was provided by Toyo Keizai.

In Japan, all institutional investors must report their holdings to the Ministry of Finance (MOF). If an institutional shareholder holds 5% or more of a firm’s outstanding shares, it must file a “large shareholdings report” with the MOF, the stock exchange, and the firm. Subsequent changes in ownership by 1% or more require filing.
The remaining shareholders are foreigners and the government.

Brennan and Cao (1997) suggest that less‐informed traders herd more than informed traders because less‐informed traders understand their informational disadvantage and thus update their priors more frequently than informed traders. Thus, our observation of less herding by Japanese institutional investors, as compared to U.S. institutional investors, can be considered consistent with our contention that Japanese institutions are better informed than U.S. institutions.

sec.title: Herding‐Year Returns
sec.p: To investigate the impact of herding by institutional investors, we examine the relationship between the change in institutional ownership and abnormal returns over the herding year. The abnormal return for each institutional ownership change portfolio is also reported intable 1. The portfolio with the largest increase in institutional ownership experiences an abnormal return of 12.81% over the herding year, statistically significant at the 1% level. This result is consistent with the hypothesis that institutional buy‐herding has an impact on stock prices. The abnormal returns steadily decrease and turn significantly negative when we go from the highest institutional ownership increase portfolio (decile 10) to the institutional ownership decrease portfolios (deciles 1, 2, and 3). Thus, the pattern of our results is similar to the monotonic relationship between herding and price movement found by Nofsinger and Sias (1999) for U.S. institutions.

Perhaps the most striking finding, however, is that the impact of herding appears to be quite dramatic in Japan, even though herding in Japan occurs at a level of only one‐third that in the United States. The range of returns between Japanese herd‐bought stocks and herd‐sold stocks is almost 18% (12.81% for decile 10 versus −5.14% for decile 1). For the United States, the range of these returns is 31.5%. Therefore, a herding level one‐third of that in the United States, results in a price impact more than one‐half of that in the United States. Our finding here reveals the strength of the signal that institutional purchasing and selling has on stock prices.

At this point, we should concede that herding and its correlated stock price changes could be occurring in less than the one‐year herding period we use. Recall that our ownership data is observed on only one date during the year. Therefore, it is possible that the stock price changes earlier, or later, in the year than the time of the herding. That is, we cannot determine whether the herding occurs before, during, or after the price change within the year. However, we find it more likely that the herding and price change occur concurrently for two reasons. First, Chakravarty (2001) and Sias, Starks, and Titman (2001) conclude that a price change measured over the same period as institutional ownership changes is due to the impact of the institutional trading. Second, analysis conducted later in this paper shows that the herding and return momentum do not continue into the next year. That is, momentum does not occur after herding and herding does not occur after stock price changes, allowing us to infer that herding and the herd‐year stock price changes are occurring concurrently.

Thus far, we claim that the change in institutional ownership (herding) is related to concurrent returns. This is not to say, however, that ownership structure, in and of itself, is related to firm performance, which is a relationship subject to a contentious debate in the current literature. For example, Jensen and Meckling (1976) argue that certain ownership structures (e.g., concentrated ownership or insider ownership) can mitigate agency costs, which implies that certain types of ownership structure should lead to superior firm performance. However, Demsetz and Lehn (1985) note that firms with different ownership structures can perform equally as well. As such, they argue that a firm's ownership structure is the result of an optimization process. That is, each firm adopts, in equilibrium, the ownership structure best suited for it, and as a result, no specific ownership structure should yield superior firm performance. For Japanese firms, Prowse (1992) and Ferris, Kim, and Kitsabunnarat (2001) find no empirical relationship between various ownership structures and firm performance, supporting Demsetz and Lehn (1985). Based on the empirical findings of these latter papers, we feel that our herding results are unrelated to how ownership structure potentially affects firm performance. That is, our results should not be taken to imply that it is better to have more institutional owners. To verify this contention, we conducted an additional investigation. We sorted our firms, into portfolio‐deciles, based on their levels of institutional ownership. Recall that ownership data are reported at the fiscal year‐end. To see if there is a relationship between ownership structure and firm performance, we look at returns during the 12 months prior to the fiscal year‐end in which ownership data is reported (Pre‐Returns), and we look at returns during the 12 months after the fiscal year‐end in which ownership data is reported (Post Returns).Table 2shows the results. Fromtable 2, we see that, on average, institutional shareholders own 84% (35%) of the firms in decile 10 (1). When we look at the abnormal returns (both Pre Returns and Post Returns) among these different ownership deciles, we see no differences among them (this is verified by theF‐statistics). These results provide consistent evidence to Prowse (1992) that different Japanese ownership structures do not lead to different firm performances. More important, these findings also confirm that the institutional herding affects prices, not ownership structure effects.

Overall, based on the strong relationship we observe between herd buying (selling) and positive (negative) returns, we reject the null hypothesis that there is no relationship between herding and concurrent returns.

sec.title: Pre‐Herding‐Year Returns
sec.p: We next examine the abnormal returns in the year before the herding to investigate feedback‐trading strategies. Traders who increase ownership after high returns and decrease ownership after low returns are considered to be positive feedback (or momentum) traders (see Jegadeesh and Titman1993and Grinblatt, Titman and Wermers1995). Alternatively, traders who increase ownership after low returns are considered to be negative feedback (or contrarian) traders (see Lakonishok, Shleifer and Vishny1994and Nofsinger and Sias1999).

The pre‐herding‐year abnormal return for each institutional ownership change portfolio is reported intable 1. The abnormal returns for the two largest institutional ownership change portfolios (deciles 9 and 10) are a significant 1.59% and 4.27%, respectively. This indicates that Japanese institutional investors exhibit positive feedback trading tendencies in their buying behavior. As we go from decile 10 to decile 1, we see something of a U‐shaped pattern. In fact, for decile 1, the abnormal return is a positive 1.22%, suggesting negative feedback selling. This finding is different than U.S. institutions herding. Nofsinger and Sias (1999) find that U.S. institutions positive feedback trade in both buying and selling. As a comparison, their abnormal return in the prior year for decile 10 and decile 1 are 5.1% and −3.5%, respectively.

Perhaps a more direct method to identifying feedback‐trading behaviors would be to first sort portfolios based on past performance, then observe the subsequent change in institutional ownership that occurs for these portfolios. This way, we can see if the best performers experience a subsequent increase in institutional ownership. These results are reported intable 3. Overall, we find that stocks that experience the highest (lowest) past returns subsequently experience statistically significant increases (decreases) in institutional ownership, but the results are weak. The changes in institutional ownership are less than 0.5% (e.g., the subsequent institutional ownership increase for “Winners” is only 0.28%). Furthermore, there is no discernable pattern. For example, increases in institutional ownership occur after stocks do both well (see deciles 9 and 10) and poorly (see deciles 5 and 6). Therefore, these minor average ownership increases are most likely an artifact of a general increase in institutional ownership that occurred during parts of our sample period. From this additional investigation, therefore, we conclude that the evidence is too weak to reject the null hypothesis of no relationship between past returns and subsequent herding. Unlike U.S. institutions, it appears that Japanese institutional herding is not the result of momentum trading.5

sec.title: Post‐Herding Year
sec.p: We examine the post‐herding‐year abnormal returns for each institutional ownership change portfolio intable 1. The portfolios with the largest increases in institutional ownership (deciles 7, 8, 9, and 10) experience statistically significant negative abnormal returns in the post‐herding year. These findings are different from the United States, where positive post‐herding‐year abnormal returns have been documented (Nofsinger and Sias1999). There are three (albeit non‐mutually exclusive) explanations for our results. First, Japanese institutions may not have private information, which leads to incorrect purchasing decisions. Second, Japanese institutions may not care about short‐term profits. Finally, we could be observing some sort of short‐run return reversal behavior, especially because the herding‐year returns for these stocks are relatively large. Note that the second and third explanations are related in the sense that, if the second explanation is true, then return reversals in the markets, in and of themselves, can explain our results. We believe it is highly unlikely that Japanese institutional investors lack private information (based on our earlier discussions and findings). Therefore, we believe that Japanese institutions simply do not care about short‐term profits, a view also consistent with conventional wisdom and the existing literature discussed earlier. For example, Kang and Stulz (1996) specifically argue that management makes decisions that benefit their long‐term shareholders. It is just as important to note that these losses do not offset the gains achieved during the herding‐year, attesting to the permanence of the gains. Additionally, note that the stocks institutions sold (decile 1) continue to experience negative returns. Thus, we see that institutions do know when to sell, as these stocks continue to perform poorly from the herd‐sold year.

The other alternative explanation for the negative returns for the herd‐bought stocks is that these firms are experiencing stock return reversals independent of institutional behavior. Jegadeesh and Titman (1993) and Chan, Jegadeesh, and Lakonishok (1996) identify that stock momentum occurs in the U.S. stock market. In Japan, however, there does not seem to be a momentum effect (Chui, Titman, and Wei2000). To investigate this issue, we conducted an additional analysis. In an unreported table, we sorted stocks based on herding‐year raw returns to examine their subsequent returns to identify any serial return patterns.6Overall, we detected some evidence that past losers do better than past winners. These results are similar to Chang, McCleavey, and Rhee (1995), who find that a short‐run contrarian trading strategy in Japanese stocks is profitable. Therefore, we believe that our findings support our general claim that the post‐herding‐year negative abnormal returns for the herd‐buy portfolios are partially an artifact of a return reversal behavior in the Japanese markets.

Overall, we reject the null hypothesis that there is no relationship between herding and the subsequent year's returns. However, the results are somewhat surprising. While stocks that are herd‐sold continue to do poorly, the stocks that are herd‐bought also subsequently perform poorly. In additional tests, we see that this latter finding is partially due to return reversals that occur in the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

In the post‐herding year, we also test whether Japanese herding is related to informational cascades. That is, do Japanese institutions use other institutions' trades as a signal about firm value and, thus, follow the trades?Table 1reports the change in institutional ownership in the post‐herding year. The two deciles with the greatest change in the herding year (deciles 1 and 10) have a statistically significant change in ownership in the post‐herding year. However, the decile 10 results show that institutions subsequently sell what institutions had herd‐bought, which is contrary to a cascade explanation. Also, note that both decile 1 and 10 changes are less than one‐third of 1%. We test the autocorrelation of herding by computing the correlation between institutional ownership change between the herding year and the post‐herding year. The correlation of 0.058 is quite low. Although the estimate is statistically significant, it seems more likely that it represents a general increase in institutional ownership in the stock market that occurred during some parts of our sample period instead of extended herding due to an informational cascade.

fn.p: We used raw returns to examine momentum and reversal behavior to follow the relative strength portfolios of Jegadeesh and Titman (1993). When we use abnormal returns, we find that both past losers and past winners are poor performers. This finding suggests that risk factors may explain some of the serial return behaviors that have been documented in this literature. All results discussed here are available from the authors on request.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Herding and Business Groups
sec.p: A unique institutional feature of the Japanese corporate finance environment is the prevalent business group known as akeiretsu. In a financialkeiretsu, a diverse group of firms are interlinked through an extensive network of product‐market and financial relationships, which is solidified through corporate cross‐shareholdings. Further, these interlinked firms are centered around banks and other financial institutions that act as significant creditors and equity holders of its member firms (Nakatani1984and Prowse1990). Earlier research has found thesekeiretsunetworks to be useful: Financial institutions monitor member firms (Prowse1992and Sheard1989), banks assist firms when they are financially distressed (Hoshi, Kashyap, and Scharstein1990), corporate cross‐shareholders also actively monitor one another (Berglöf and Perotti1994), asymmetry and agency costs are reduced (Prowse1990), and debt capacity is increased (Kester1986). Additionally, with regard to firm performance, perhaps the best way to characterizekeiretsufirms is that they operate in a low‐risk, low‐return environment. The two most common explanations put forth for this observation is that thekeiretsuredistributes profits among group members (i.e., mutual insurance) or this environment is consistent with the interests of the group's creditors (Nakatani1984; Weinstein and Yafeh 1998; Hoshi and Kashyap2001; and Yafeh2002).

Because the existence of thekeiretsuorganizational structure represents the most unique feature of the Japanese corporate finance environment (Hoshi, Kashyap, and Scharfstein1991), we investigate a possiblekeiretsueffect in our study.7So far, we have described how institutional shareholders are different in Japan than in the United States. For example, financial institutions are significant, influential shareholders in Japan, unlike the United States (Hoshi, Kashyap, and Scharfstein1990). However, governance mechanisms, asymmetry and agency costs, capital structure, and liquidity have been found to be quite different betweenkeiretsuand independent firms. As a result of these differences, it is argued thatkeiretsufirms and their shareholders enjoy reduced information asymmetry, incentive, and conflict of interest problems. Therefore, we expect that herding inkeiretsufirms is a stronger signal about firm value than herding in independent firms.

To investigate the existence of a possiblekeiretsueffect, we split our sample intokeiretsufirms and non‐keiretsu(i.e., independent) firms.8The null hypothesis is that there is no difference in herding behaviors and outcomes betweenkeiretsuand non‐keiretsufirms. Fromtable 4, panel A, for bothkeiretsuand independent firms, we see that they experience the same strong pattern between buying or selling and abnormal returns. Firms that are bought have large positive returns and firms that are sold have negative abnormal returns. However, we see thatkeiretsufirms with the largest increase in institutional ownership (decile 10) experience larger positive abnormal returns than bought non‐keiretsufirms andkeiretsufirms with the greatest decrease in institutional ownership (deciles 1 and 2) experience larger negative abnormal returns than the sold non‐keiretsufirms. The formal industrial organization of thekeiretsuallows for even greater access to private information than for independent Japanese firms. Therefore, it appears that the selling and buying ofkeiretsufirms, as compared to non‐keiretsufirms, sends a much stronger signal of their long‐run prospects, which is reflected by the larger price changes forkeiretsufirms sold and bought.

We present pre‐herding‐year results intable 4, panel B. By examining the pre‐herding‐year firm performance, it may be possible to identify the motivation behind the herding‐year buying or selling of institutional investors. The most interesting result from this panel is that the weak evidence of positive feedback buying behavior discussed earlier appears to be limited to the non‐keiretsufirms. For stocks that non‐keiretsufirms herd‐buy, deciles 9 and 10, the prior year's abnormal returns are a statistically significant 2.74% and 5.71%, respectively. In stark contrast, it appears that institutions do not rely on momentum in their herding ofkeiretsufirms. The differences in decile 9 and 10 pre‐herding‐year returns, betweenkeiretsufirms and non‐keiretsufirms, are statistically significant at the 1% level. As such, this result is consistent with the view that owners ofkeiretsufirms do not rely as heavily on past performance in their buying decisions, as they are able to rely more on private information. The subsequent herding‐year returns (referring back to the panel A results) supports this conjecture, as we see that herd‐bought and herd‐soldkeiretsufirms outperform non‐keiretsufirms.

Table 4, panel C, shows post‐herding‐year results.keiretsufirms that are herd‐sold subsequently perform more poorly than non‐keiretsufirms that are herd‐sold. Further, we see no difference betweenkeiretsuand non‐keiretsufirms that were herd‐bought. Ifkeiretsufirms, as opposed to non‐keiretsufirms, care more about the long run rather than the short run and their shareholders have more private information, then the explanations for the panel C results are thatkeiretsufirms know when to sell (i.e., using private information) and they care less about capturing short‐run gains of what they buy (i.e., focusing on the long term).

Overall, when we examine herding‐year abnormal returns, we detect a significant difference betweenkeiretsuand independent firms that indicates thatkeiretsufirm owners are better informed than non‐keiretsufirm owners. When we observe pre‐herding‐year returns to detect possible motivations for purchasing decisions, we see thatkeiretsufirm shareholders do not use past performance as a basis for what they buy, but that non‐keiretsufirm shareholders seem to buy past winners. Finally, when we look at post‐herding year returns, we see thatkeiretsufirms know when to sell but may not care about the short‐run profits to what they buy.

Before we conclude this section, we address two final issues. First, much has been stated in the popular press that thekeiretsu's power and influence has been in decline in recent years.9Yafeh (2002) and Hoshi and Kashyap (2001) also point out that the power and size of these cross‐shareholdings are in decline, perhaps, in part, due to the “Big Bang” liberalization that took place in the late 1990s. These contentions suggest that ourkeiretsuresults may be driven primarily by earlier time periods. We conduct various subperiod analyses to verify this contention. Overall, additional subperiod tests comparingkeiretsufirms to non‐keiretsufirms yield consistent findings to our full sample period findings.10However, we observe that much of our earlier documented findings are stronger during earlier time periods, which is wherekeiretsuties are conjectured to have been stronger. In fact, when we look at a subperiod from 1998 to 2001, we find very little difference betweenkeiretsufirms and non‐keiretsufirms in their herding tendencies and effects. This finding lends credence to the belief that thekeiretsuis losing its economic significance and power.

A second issue that merits investigation involves the well‐known fact that Japanese banks have been experiencing significant loan‐loss problems since 1994 (e.g., see Fukao2002and Hoshi and Kashyap2001). To cover these losses, some banks sold equity to realize capital gains (Fukao2002). Becausekeiretsubanks are among the largest in Japan, there is a chance that our results focusing on the difference betweenkeiretsufirms and non‐keiretsufirms are somehow affected by an indiscriminate selling of shares bykeiretsubanks. That is, selling bykeiretsushareholders may not be such a strong signal about the firm after 1994 because the selling may be motivated by needs of the shareholders, not the prospects of the firm. To investigate this issue, we examine the post‐1994 selling behavior ofkeiretsufinancial institutions. We detect similar herding period returns between firms thatkeiretsufinancial institutions herd‐sell to those that non‐keiretsufinancial institutions herd‐sell.

For the post‐herd year returns, we see no difference between herd‐boughtkeiretsufirms and herd‐soldkeiretsufirms. When we exclude the post‐1994 years of our study sample, the resulting empirical observations are still qualitatively similar (and in many cases they are sharper) to those already reported intable 4.11

Overall, because we document significant differences betweenkeiretsufirms and non‐keiretsufirms, especially with regard to price impacts during the herding‐year and with regard to feedback trading and because these effects are stronger when thekeiretsuis posited to have been more influential and powerful, we reject the null hypothesis that there are no differences in the herding behaviors between firms associated with significant business groups and firms not associated with business groups.

fn.p: We should mention that recent papers by Miwa and Ramseyer (2002a,2002b) strongly challenge the idea that thekeiretsuis, or ever has been, important in the Japanese economy. They even contend that the existence of thekeiretsuis largely a myth. Note that our null hypothesis is that there is no difference between ourkeiretsu‐classified firms and our non‐keiretsu‐classified firms, which is consistent with Miwa and Ramseyer’s contention. However, our subsequent empirical results reject this null hypothesis.

Thekeiretsuclassification scheme we adopt is Dodwell Marketing Consultants’ (1985,1989). Their definition considers the group’s influential power, which is measured by the ratio of the group members’ shareholding to the total shares held by the top 10 shareholders. In addition, thekeiretsuclassification is also based on the following factors: (1) the characteristics and historical background of the group and the company, (2) the different of sources and amounts of bank loans, (3) whether or not board members come from other group companies, (4) the company’s attitude toward the group, and (5) the company’s connections to nongroup companies and to other groups. We also investigate whether or not a specifickeiretsugroup drives ourkeiretsuresults. We find that this is not the case.
For example, see Abrahams and Tett (1999) and Dvorak, Guth, Singer, and Zaun (2001) in theFinancial Timesand theWall Street Journal, respectively.

Because thekeiretsuversus non‐keiretsusubperiod results are qualitatively similar to the full sample period results, we chose to not report them for the sake of brevity. However, all results are available from the authors.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: Herding and Economic Regimes
sec.p: Aside from studying a unique group of institutional investors and thekeiretsuorganizational structure, Japan also offers the opportunity to study different economic environments. In its recent past, Japan has experienced at least four distinct economic regimes. During the 1980s, there was mass financial market liberalization in the form of interest rate deregulation and the removal of bond and foreign market restrictions (for more details, see Hoshi, Kashyap, and Scharfstein1993; Hoshi1996; Kang and Stulz1996; Kim and Limpaphayom1997; and Weinstein and Yafeh1998). Prior to deregulation, all firms primarily relied on bank debt. With the creation of an active secondary government bond market, the removal of corporate bond issuance restrictions, and the ability to finally access foreign markets, firms enjoyed greater financing flexibility (Hoshi1996; Kang and Stulz1996; and Weinstein and Yafeh1998). Consequently, from the early 1980s to the end of the 1980s, the Japanese market experienced tremendous growth. From the beginning of 1984 to the end of 1989, the Tokyo Stock Price Index (TOPIX) grew 294%, with double‐digit growth every year and an average annual return of 26.3% (Tokyo Stock Exchange1997). This time period is widely known as Japan's bubble economy (French and Poterba1991; and Kang and Stulz1996,2000).

In 1990, however, the Japanese economy experienced an enormous crash (the TOPIX plummeted by 40%) and the market became flat, with an average annual return of approximately −5% from 1990 to 1997. In light of the bearish market, major reforms known as the “Big Bang” were proposed and adopted. The Big Bang represented a complete deregulation of the financial system. More specifically, the Big Bang increased investment options to investors and capital‐raising options to corporations. It allowed financial institutions to offer more services and it attempted to create a more efficient and “fair” financial market (for more details about the Big Bang, see Hoshi and Kashyap2001). From this study's viewpoint, perhaps the key Big Bang reform is that firms became much less reliant on bank financing.

To examine herding and feedback trading during these distinct economic regimes, we split our sample into four subperiod categories: 1975‐83, 1984‐89, 1990‐97, and 1998‐2001. The choice for using the 1983 year‐end as our first splitting point is motivated by Kim and Limpaphayom (1997) and Weinstein and Yafeh (1998). Both identify 1984 as the beginning in which the effects of deregulation can be observed. The choice of the 1989 year‐end as our second splitting point is motivated by Kang and Stulz (1996,2000), who identify 1990 as the beginning of the Japanese economic downturn. Finally, the choice for the 1997 year‐end as our third splitting point is based on our own determination, while noting that the substance of the Big Bang proposals were announced and immediately acted on during 1997 (see Hoshi and Kashyap2001, page 295, for more details).

While the current herding and feedback models and literature do not give us explicit predictions on the affect of herding in bull versus bear markets, Welch (2000) provides some relevant insights. He finds that herding toward the consensus is stronger during bullish markets and consequently suggests that less information is being aggregated during good times. These contentions suggest that we will observe herding at greater levels during bull markets. In addition, intuitively, we might expect that buy‐herding (sell‐herding) is relatively more important during bull (bear) markets. As for the Big Bang period, we might conjecture that financial institutions will now become more like active investors. Japanese financial institutions were previously known to maintain equity stakes simply to monitor their positions as creditors. But, with firms reducing their reliance on bank financing, these financial institutions are now in a position to view their equity holdings as pure investments. A similar prediction can be drawn from Hoshi and Kashyap (2001), as they suggest that financial institutions may decrease their corporate governance involvement during the Big Bang era. For the most part, however, we concede all these expectations are largely conjectural. As such, we consider our subperiod investigation to be exploratory in nature. Note.—Each year, for four subperiods (1975–83, 1984–89, 1990–97, and 1998–2001), all nonfinancial TSE firms are sorted into 10 portfolios based on the fraction of shares held by institutions. The firms in each initial institutional‐ownership decile are then further sorted into 10 portfolios based on the change in the fraction of shares held by institutions over the following year (for a total of 100 portfolios). Firms are then reaggregated based on their change in ownership‐decile rank resulting in 10 “initial‐stratified ownership‐change” portfolios. Abnormal returns are compounded monthly capitalization‐decile‐ and book‐to‐market‐decile‐adjusted returns. Panel A reports the change in institutional ownership, panel B reports the Herding‐Year abnormal returns, panel C reports the Pre‐Herding‐Year abnormal returns, and panel D reports the Post‐Herding‐Year abnormal returns. Thet‐statistics are reported in parentheses. TheF‐statistics reported in the last column test the null hypothesis that abnormal returns do not differ across ownership change portfolios, within each subperiod. TheF‐statistics reported in the last row of each panel test the null hypothesis that abnormal returns do not differ among subperiods, within each change decile. ***, **, and * denote statistical significance at the 1%, 5%, and 10% levels, respectively.

Panel A shows the change in institutional ownership for the four economic periods. First, we note that the difference between the largest institutional ownership increase and decrease portfolios (Decile 10 – Decile 1) occurs during the bull market (15.9% difference) with the narrowest difference occurring during the bear market (10.8% difference). This observation is consistent with Welch's (2000) finding that consensus herding is stronger during bull markets. Second, within each decile, we see that the largest institutional ownership percent increase occurs during the bull market period. The lowest institutional ownership percent increase, within each decile, occurs during the overall bear market periods of 1990–97 and 1998–2001. For example, the institutional‐ownership increase in decile 10 is 10.7% during the bull market but only 4.7% during the 1990–97 bear market. Also, note that, during the bull market, only three deciles experience average institutional ownership declines, while seven deciles experience institutional ownership declines during the bear market. Overall, these observations are consistent with the conjecture that institutional herd‐buying is more active during the bull market, while institutional selling is more common during the bear market. Finally, for the Big Bang subperiod, we notice large institutional ownership decreases in deciles 1–7, relative to the other subperiods. One possible explanation for this selling activity is that financial institutions were reducing their equity stakes because their interest as important creditors was diminishing.

Herding‐year abnormal returns are reported in panel B. We see that the results to herding are greatest during the bull market and smallest during the overall bear markets of 1990–97 and 1998–2001. For the bull period, the abnormal price increase to the herd‐bought portfolio (decile 10) is 18.69% and the abnormal price decrease for the herd‐sold portfolio (decile 1) is −9.08%, which yields a range of almost 28%. In contrast, this same range measured during the bear market period is only 8.38%. Our results reveal the importance of both herd‐buying and ‐selling when the overall market is expanding. For the Big Bang subperiod, the range of herding‐year returns expands from the earlier 1990–97 subperiod. Specifically, for herd‐buying (herd‐selling), the herd returns are 17.8 (−5.33)%, which represents a return range of over 23%. If financial institutions are becoming more like investors rather than monitors, then their buying and selling activities represent stronger signals. Consistent with this contention, we again find that financial institutions play a significant role in driving these latter results.

Panel C reports pre‐herding‐year abnormal returns. In the full sample, we found only weak evidence of positive feedback trading, which occurred in the buying of past winners. Further analysis showed no feedback trading inkeiretsufirms. Here, we see some negative feedback in selling behavior during the regulated market period and some positive feedback trading in buying behavior during the bull market period. However, the results for the bear market period are stronger. Institutional herding in the bear market period appears to be associated with positive feedback trading in both buying and selling. The Big Bang subperiod shows very significant positive feedback buying behavior (decile 10), revealing their buying preferences and investing strategies as those of investors rather than just creditors.

Finally, Panel D, which reports post‐herding‐year returns, reveals that the short‐run impact of herding is somewhat similar across all four subperiods. Earlier, we argued that short‐run outcomes do not seem to be a determinant of herd behavior, therefore we would expect these results to be related more to the propensity for return reversals, meaning that subperiods with larger herding‐year returns are likely to experience larger negative post‐herding‐year returns. The decile 10 results generally seem to support this contention.

For convenience, we provide a figure that shows the abnormal return differences between buy portfolios (decile 10) and sell portfolios (decile 1) for each year.Figure 1reveals that the tendency of changes in institutional buying accompanying large abnormal returns is robust across years, though weaker in the bear market period. The underperformance during the post‐herding year is consistent across all periods. For the pre‐herding‐year returns, we see that the patterns fluctuate across years. These results are generally consistent with thetable 5findings. One interesting result highlighted in the figure, however, is the similarity between the bull market period and the Big Bang period. Note that both periods follow significant deregulation. Fig. 1.—
The figure shows the difference in returns, each year, for the largest increase in institutional ownership decile (10) less the largest decrease in ownership decile (1). Specifically, the abnormal return difference (decile 10 ‐ decile 1) for the pre‐herding, herding, and post‐herding years are shown along with the difference in the change in ownership.

Overall, the subperiod results highlight the importance of differentiating economic environments when studying the behavior of institutional investors. First, we note that herding had a greater price impact during the bull market of 1984–89 and during the Big Bang subperiod, than during the bear market of 1990–97. Second, we also see that feedback‐trading strategies appear to differ among subperiods as well, especially between the bull and bear markets. However, differences in post‐herding‐year returns appear marginal across all subperiods. Nonetheless, due to the former two findings, we reject the null hypothesis that there are no differences in herding behaviors across subperiods.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Summary
sec.p: In this paper, we examine herding and feedback trading in Japan. In Japan, institutional investors have fewer restrictions, than in the United States, when it comes to equity shareholdings. As a result, Japanese institutional investors are generally known to be long‐term shareholders that are active and influential toward the firms in which they own shares. Also, in Japan, some firms belong to a business group known as akeiretsu. Thus, even within the Japanese market, we are able to examine herding and feedback trading under different institutional arrangements (i.e.,keiretsufirms versus non‐keiretsufirms). Finally, the Japanese economy experienced four distinct economic regimes in its recent past: a regulated period, a bull market, a bear market, and a dramatically deregulated period known as the “Big Bang.” Therefore, we are also able to examine herding and feedback trading under different economic environments.

Investors with minimum informational asymmetry relative to other investors are able to make trading decisions on private information about firm value. Herding based on this superior information is referred to asinvestigative herding. Investors who have high information asymmetry must make trading decisions based on signals they perceive to be correlated with firm value. For example, institutions may think other investors are better informed and follow their trades. This causes herding based on informational cascades. Or, investors may herd on other signals, like firm characteristics. Herding on one characteristic, return momentum, is referred to aspositive feedback trading. Empirical tests in the U.S. market suggest that institutional herding can be characterized as positive feedback trading and informational cascades. However, given the long‐term nature of institutional ownership in Japan, we propose that Japanese institutional herding is more likely to be consistent with investigative herding.

Our first empirical finding is that the level of herding in Japan is only about one‐third the level in the United States. However, we find that herding in Japan has a price impact over one‐half of that found in the United States. While herding occurs on a lower scale in Japan, when it does occur, it has a dramatic effect on prices. We argue that the first finding is an artifact of the long‐term nature of institutional ownership in Japan, while the latter finding is an artifact of the institutional owners' private information (i.e., their selling or buying is a strong signal). When we examine the prior performance of firms that institutions buy and sell, we find no compelling evidence that Japanese institutions are feedback traders. When we examine the year after herding, we find that herd‐bought firms experience negative abnormal returns, but a follow‐up analysis reveals that much of these negative returns are due primarily to a return reversal effect. Just as important, the reversals do not offset the gains that are achieved during the herd‐year. We also examine the level of ownership change following the herding year. We find no evidence of a continuation in herding. Therefore, we conclude that Japanese herding is more closely related to investigative herding than feedback trading or informational cascades.

Much of our full sample findings are stronger for a subsample ofkeiretsufirms. Most notably, the price impact of herding forkeiretsufirms is much larger than for non‐keiretsufirms.keiretsufirms, unlike non‐keiretsufirms, seem to not rely on past stock performance for their buying decisions. Both of these observations are stronger during an earlier time period, where thekeiretsudistinction is posited to have been more economically meaningful. Therefore, these findings are consistent with the view that owners ofkeiretsufirms (especially when thekeiretsuis strong) have access to more private information than owners of non‐keiretsufirms, which is not surprising given the intimate nature of strongkeiretsunetworks.

Finally, we conduct subperiod analyses of herding on a regulated period, a bull market, a bear market, and the Big Bang period. The results reveal that institutional herd‐buying is more (less) active during bull (bear) markets. Further, the price impact of both herd‐buying and herd‐selling is much greater during a bull market. Additionally, any evidence of feedback trading seems to be concentrated in the bear market period, when Japanese institutions appear to buy past winners and sell past losers. Finally, we find that much of the patterns found during the bear market do not carry into the Big Bang period. Therefore, these subperiod findings reveal the importance of different economic environments when examining herding and feedback trading behaviors. We hope this stimulates the development of herding models that explore the effects of different economic environments.
